model.name: ImplementingSTEEPMethodology-Step7
model.desc: The seventh step in implementing the STEEP methodology focusses on the use of argumentation to resolve process performance issues.

node.name: Implementing the STEEP methodology
node.desc:
The complete documentation set for the STEEP methodology can be found on the STEEP website at http://smartsteep.eu/resources
The methodology as described here is designed for deployment on the STEEP collaborative stakeholder engagement platform as an aid to implementation.
Without getting too recursive, the transformational system at this stage is bootstrapping itself and the two processes to address for now are <Animating the methodology> and <Deciding the system boundary>. This will lead to the next stage.

node.name: Enrolling stakeholders
node.desc: Largely addressed by <Creating a sense of ownership>

node.name: Deciding system boundary
node.desc: This provides the initial scope for implementation. Basic considerations are time, geographic extent and focus e.g. energy planning in Bristol for next 20 years

node.name: Deciding transformation goal
node.desc: See sub-processes

node.name: Animating the methodology
node.desc: This is crucial. There must be some animating force that initially drives the implementation of the STEEP methodology. This platform goes a certain way towards supporting this process but eventually must be owned by the stakeholders.

node.name: Appreciating theoretical foundations
node.desc: See sub-processes

node.name: Being aware of the GCD
node.desc:
Awareness of the 9 Apsects of the Generic Constitutive Definition (GCD) of Problem Structuirng Methods (PSM) will help adapting the STEEP methodology as required:
1 Improvement Activity A structured approach to systemic intervention, designed to lead to improvements in a problematic real-world situation 2 Systemic Approach The problem structuring approach used systems ideas supported by appropriate systems modelling (amongst other requirements) 3 Adaptation/ Creativity Creativity must have gone into how the problem structuring approach was adapted or elements combined for the particular problem situation 4 Methodological Lessons Use of the approach led to methodological lessons 5 Worldviews Recognition that problems are construct of an individual’s mind, they do not exist independently of human thought and are defined by an individual’s “worldview” 6 Messiness The problem context in which the problem structuring approach was used was recognised as messy following definitions such as contained in this paper 7 Interactive/ Iterative/ Therapeutic The intervention has come about through sharing of “perceptions, persuasion and debate” in a participative group setting using an interactive and iterative approach. The facilitator adopted a stance that was “interactive/therapeutic, not expert” 8 Subjectivity In the approach taken it has been recognised that the stakeholders of the problem situation are not “divorced from the problem” 9 Limits The approach dealt with conceptual limitations of modelling language used
See: Yearworth, M., & White, L. (2014). The non-codified use of problem structuring methods and the need for a generic constitutive definition. European Journal of Operational Research, 237(3), 932-945. doi: 10.1016/j.ejor.2014.02.015

node.name: Understanding nature of wicked/messy problems
node.desc:
Baased on Rittel, H.W.J., & Webber, M.M. (1973). Dilemmas in a General Theory of Planning. Policy Sciences, 4(2), 155-169. and others, for example see Yearworth, M. (2015). Sustainability as a “super wicked” problem; opportunities and limits for engineering methodology. Paper presented at the 7th International Conference on Sustainable Development in Building and Environment (SuDBE 2015), Reading, UK.
1. No definitive formulation 2. No stopping rule 3. Solutions are not right or wrong, there is no immediate or ultimate test of a solution, but can only be viewed as good or bad 4. Solutions are ‘one-shot’, there can be no trial-and-error (experiments); every intervention counts significantly, they are essentially unique 5. No enumerable, exhaustively describable, set of solutions 6. Can be considered as symptoms of other problems 7. Can be contested at the level of explanation, there is likely to be conflicting evidence/data 8. Aim is intervention, not knowledge gathering for its own sake

node.name: Knowing about soft systems
node.desc: Best reference to use here would be Checkland, P., & Holwell, S. (2004). "Classic" OR and "soft" OR - an asymmetric complementarity. In M. Pidd (Ed.), Systems Modelling: Theory and Practice. Chichester: John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

node.name: Tool/platform support
node.desc: the recommended approach to providing tool support for the STEEP methodology is to use the STEEP collaborative stakeholder engagement platform, although this isn't necessary to be succesful. The process can work without any tool support.

node.name: Appreciating basics about systems thinking
node.desc: A suituable source to be recommended

node.name: Facilitating the process
node.desc: It is unclear at the moment whether <animating the methodology> can ever be completely succesful without someone enacting the specific role of facilitator. It is an area of ongoing research e.g. see Franco, L.A. (2007). Assessing the impact of problem structuring methods in multi-organizational settings: An empirical investigation. Journal of the Operational Research Society, 58(6), 760-768. Morton, A., Ackermann, F., & Belton, V. (2007). Problem structuring without workshops? Experiences with distributed interaction within a PSM process. Journal of the Operational Research Society, 58(5), 547-556. doi: 10.1057/palgrave.jors.2602210 Shaw, D., Westcombe, M., Hodgkin, J., & Montibeller, G. (2004). Problem structuring methods for large group interventions. Journal of the Operational Research Society, 55(5), 453-463. doi: 10.1057/palgrave.jors.2601712 Yearworth, M. (2015). Sustainability as a “super wicked” problem; opportunities and limits for engineering methodology. Paper presented at the 7th International Conference on Sustainable Development in Building and Environment (SuDBE 2015), Reading, UK.

node.name: Maintaining stakeholder ownership
node.desc: See sub-processes

node.name: Creating a sense of ownership
node.desc: Crucial! Without this the whole methodology implementation stalls.

node.name: Understanding overall purpose of system
node.desc: The methodology brings about a conceptual system to understand how a transformation is to be achieved. Achieving the transformational goal can be thought of as the purpose of this conceptual system.

node.name: Developing a root definition
node.desc:
This is the mechanism by which a transformational goal is derived and expressed based on Soft Systems Methodology (SSM). See Checkland, P., & Scholes, J. (1999). Soft Systems Methodology in Action: Including a 30-year retrospective. Chichester: Wiley.
for a practical guide.

node.name: Appreciating worldviews
node.desc:
See White, L., Yearworth, M., & Burger, K. (2015). Understanding PSM Interventions through Sense-making and the Mangle of Practice Lens. Paper presented at the 15th International Conference on Group Decision and Negotiation (GDN 2015), Warsaw, Poland.
For an analysis which demonstrates how this works on a workshop setting.

node.name: Implementing engagement strategies
node.desc: These must be ongoing throughtout the period of implementation of the STEEP methodology

node.name: Building shared mental models of the transformation
node.desc: This is the basic core of the modelling methodology

node.name: System modelling
node.desc: The actual process of building conceptual systems models using the HPM approach

node.name: Understanding the HPM approach
node.desc:
Understanding the HPM approach. Further details can be found at http://smartsteep.eu/resources
A system can represented by a network of “blobs” and “links” Hierarchy offers us a way of managing complexity System represented as a hierarchical arrangement of system elements Each level the same but expressed in more detail – decomposition Decomposition is the simple link  Step 1 in the modelling language we will use. There is only one kind of link – a decomposition
A system can represented by a network of “blobs” and “links” The “blob” is conceived as a transformational entity, a process Anything can be a process
 Step 2 in the common language. There is only one form of blob - a process

node.name: Knowing when to stop
node.desc: Appreciating that system modelling using processes needs to go on for as long as it takes to build an understanding of the problem situation, and until the stakeholders run out of process answers to 'how' questions and start to run into issues and options. The beginning of the IBIS/EDEN process.

node.name: Appreciating the need for gerund form
node.desc: Described by gerunds - in English these are words ending in –ing. They have no subject, and the agent (performer) is not specified Originating from Latin grammar, gerund can be translated as “(which is) to be carried out” using the active present (or continuous) form.

node.name: Understanding the how/why dialectic
node.desc: Using the soft systems paradigm our system model is an epistemic device that will be used to decide how to intervene in a messy problem situation The system model is a conceptual schema for enacting a transformation, which can be thought of as its purpose Eliciting hierarchical system structure starts with a top level process and then proceeds through repeated questioning of how? Modelling continues until there is no longer a process answer to the how? questions and issues/options need to be resolved

node.name: Appreciating the Holon concept
node.desc: A holon is a conceptual, abstract, representation of a whole, which is also a part Used as an intellectual device to think about the world Using conceptual models that consist of processes, described by gerunds, structured into a hierarchical arrangement by decomposition and representing the minimum processes in a system required to achieve a purpose

node.name: Evidencing process performance using Italian Flag notation
Understanding Italian Flags and Interval Numbers
node.desc:
Messy problem context suggests we have an existing view of a system Motivation for intervention is recognition amongst stakeholders it is failing in some way Need a means to express the likelihood ‘success being achieved’ i.e. way of flagging issues and knowing when things improve We use estimates of process performance using interval numbers
Simplest approach to judging process performance Within a group of experts/process owners Based on a process of debate to decide between Performing well, good,… Don’t know, unknown, need more information… Not performing well, poor, …

node.name: Debating evidence and entering evidence into model
node.desc: Exactly that

node.name: Dealing with possible inconsistencies
node.desc:
This is described more fully in Yearworth, M., Lowe, D.A., Schien, D., & Walworth, T. (2015). From deciding to acting: hierarchical process modelling for problem structuring. Paper presented at the Calculating and Communicating Uncertainty (CCU2015), London, UK.
Likely to be not much of an issue unless actually working with the PeriMeta software, or any other algorithm that implements evidence propagation. See Marashi, S.E., Davis, J.P., & Hall, J.W. (2008). Combination methods and conflict handling in evidential theories. International Journal of Uncertainty Fuzziness and Knowledge-Based Systems, 16(3), 337-369. doi: 10.1142/s0218488508005315

node.name: Being clear about HPM as a PSM
node.desc: This means that it is understood that we are really using the model as an epistemic device to aid problem understanding. How do we achieve the stated transformation. The evidence points towards processes that are performing poorly or there is lack of information. These become the focus for action i.e. red=>fix and white=>find-out more.

node.name: Deciding options using IBIS/EDEN
node.desc: See sub-processes

node.name: Understanding IBIS/EDEN
node.desc:
Issues Based Information Systems (IBIS)/Evidential Discourse in ENgineering (EDEN) Type of information system designed to support cooperatives confronted by complex problems and needing to arrive at a plan of action Rests on a model of problem solving by cooperatives as an argumentative process Starts from an unstructured problem situation or topic, named as a trigger phrase, from which a discourse develops Issues are brought up and disputed Arguments are constructed for/against until the issue is settled
Different types of information exchanges occur Between participants With experts specifically consulted Factual literature and outputs from modelling Sub-cooperatives Makes the argumentation visible i.e. provides documentation/reporting
Issues: a point of discussion to be resolved about the performance or state of knowledge about a process Options: a possible intervention to resolve the issue Arguments: support or refute an option Appear as elements in the process map under processes in the order Process <-Issues <-Options <-Arguments
This uses the EDEN/IBIS capabilities of the modelling approach. Described fully in Marashi, E., & Davis, J.P. (2006). An argumentation-based method for managing complex issues in design of infrastructural systems. Reliability Engineering & System Safety, 91(12), 1535-1545. doi: 10.1016/j.ress.2006.01.013 Marashi, E., & Davis, J. (2007). A Systems-Based Approach for Supporting Discourse in Decision Making. Computer-Aided Civil and Infrastructure Engineering, 22, 511-526. Davis, J.P., & Hall, J.W. (2003). A software-supported process for assembling evidence and handling uncertainty in decision-making. Decision Support Systems, 35(3), 415-433. doi: 10.1016/s0167-9236(02)00117-3 Yearworth, M., Schien, D., & Burger, K. (2014). D2.1 R1 Energy Master Plan Process Modelling STEEP PROJECT (314277) - Systems Thinking for Comprehensive City Efficient Energy Planning (pp. 70): University of Bristol.

node.name: Arriving at a list of options
node.desc: See sub-processes

node.name: Translating measurements into Italian Flags
node.desc: See training material at http://smartsteep.eu/resources for approaches to this

node.name: Use the STEEP collabortive stakeholder engagement platform
Use CATWOE
node.desc: See STEEP deliverable D2.1 for a complete description Yearworth, M., Schien, D., & Burger, K. (2014). D2.1 R1 Energy Master Plan Process Modelling STEEP PROJECT (314277) - Systems Thinking for Comprehensive City Efficient Energy Planning (pp. 70): University of Bristol.

node.name: Strategies to resolve
node.desc: This requires an understanding that inconsistency is a result of System Structure? Evidence? Necessity/Sufficiency conditions? In Step 6 as an example, we address inconsistency by changing necessity and sufficiency values. Note that they are back at default values for PeriMeta.
